comment.narrative: 1.Insufficient up to date research and lack of analytical studies for the governmental officials on the issues related to the WTO accession process in general and probable implications for regional economic and trade alliances resulting from WTO accession by their members, in particular. 2. Insufficient public awareness regarding WTO rules and country's accession process among target audiences of business community, academia and the media.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

1. Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings. 2. Demonstrated capacity of the Belarussian building sector specialist to integrate new EE approaches and measures into the design of the buildings and to implement them in practice. 3. comment.narrative: 1. Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory U-values for the building envelope, corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWh/m2 for space heating of typical multi-apartment buildings and 120-130 kWh /m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation. 2. Non-integrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force. Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new, overall energy performance based norms and standards. 3. No demonstration projects implemented. 4. No public outreach activities implemented.

1. Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory U-values for the building envelope, corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWh/m2 for space heating of typical multi-apartment buildings and 120-130 kWh /m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation. 2. Non-integrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force. Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new, overall energy performance based norms and standards. 3. N/A 4. N/A

1. The level is still the same as for the baseline. Although the Project helped formulate and draft new technical norms establishing building energy performance below 60 kWh/m2 per year (space heating and hot water supply), which were adopted, but these norms are not required by law. The Technical Code "Energy Efficiency of Buildings" (a law status), which was initiated and drafted by the Project, has been already passed the conciliation procedure and submitted to the Council of Ministers for adoption. It is expected that the Code will come into force in the beginning of 2017. The energy performance certification scheme has been also developed. The related article has been integrated in the said Technical Code. 2. In average, more than 50 experts from each of three professional groups (designers, construction inspectors, builders and policy-makers) have passed related courses including two practical courses with the Minsk pilot construction site visits for construction engineers. There are already 7 local design institutes (NIPTIS, MAPID, Hrodnagrazhdanproekt, Gomelgrazhdanproekt, Saint-Gobain Construction Product BelRus, Tenth UNR, Minskproekt), i.e., 3% out of ca. 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering, which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project. Two leading universities, i.e., Belarusian National Technical University and Belarusian State Technological University have adopted new courses on energy efficient building design and construction elaborated by the Project, and already more than 300 students in these universities are attending these courses. 3. The level is the same as for the baseline. The pilot buildings in Mahiliou and Minsk have been already commissioned but have not been inhabited yet. The pilot building in Hrodna is still under construction. 4. The level is the same as for the

1. The quality standards and a system of energy efficiency certification for the materials, equipment and component parts used in residential construction have been formally submitted for adoption. 2. Adoption of the integrated energy efficient building design approach together with buildings’ overall energy performance based design principles is made by increased number of design organisations with the target of at least 30% of all local design institutes by the end of the project. 3.The construction of demonstration buildings has been completed in line with the prepared design specifications and estimates, proposed energy efficiency standards and other quality standards and guidelines. The buildings have been placed in service. 4. State agency to take on the responsibility of monitoring energy saving and GHG emissions in the residential sector, and the procedure for the collection of necessary raw data, reporting and recording of these parameters has been proposed by the project, reviewed and adopted by the authorized government body; and the respective interagency agreement has been prepared.

1. The Technical Code "Energy Efficiency of Buildings", a regulatory enactment that contains, inter alia, the minimum energy performance requirements, corresponding provisions for energy certification and compliance checking systems and energy audit was finally approved by the Technical Committee on Standardization in the Field of Architecture & Construction (TCS-14) and was incorporated into the State List of Technical Norms & Standards Pending Adoption. The Ministry of Architecture & Construction was assigned to develop a list of interrelated standards and national addenda and to elaborate a plan of measures for introduction of the Code by the end of 2017. 2. 13% of local design organizations are introducing in their practice the design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project. 3. All three pilot energy efficient buildings have been commissioned (in Mahiliou - Dec 2016, Minsk - Jan 2017, Hrodna - May 2017). The buildings have been inhabited by 25-30%. 4. Basic provisions and principles for a system that provides monitoring and analysis of data on energy savings and the methodology for calculation of GHG emissions in the housing sector were handed over to RUE Belarusian Research Centre "Ecology", mandated to perform activities related to the country's commitments under the UNFCC. Further communication will be held to develop and establish the system for monitoring energy saving and GHG emissions in the housing sector.

description.narrative: To reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: Lifetime reduction of 220000 tons of CO2eq resulting from the energy saving in buildings for which the construction has started or which have adopted into their design new energy efficiency elements that reduce the energy consumption for heating and hot water in the residential buildings below the current thermal standards in force

179 thousand tons of CO2eq
The design and construction documentations for three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk developed by the project have been submitted for the required state expertise New energy efficiency measures have been adopted into the design of these buildings ventilation heat recuperation heat pumps on sewage and geothermal sources solar heaters and solar PVpanels The project has been already proceeded to procurement of related equipment accessories and tools These provisions allow the projected annual specific energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply to be in the range of 5060 kWhm2 that is by ca 6070 kWhm2 per year lower than in the baseline case
If this design value is proven by actual construction the lifetime 30 years GHG emission reduction will be at least 179 thousand tons of CO2eq for the three buildings in total

description.narrative: Number of buildings designed and constructed in accordance with the new energy efficiency standards

comment.narrative: At least 10 around 80 buildings of all new residential multistorey buildings for which the design is started during the last year of the project are integrating new EE measures into their design with the target of reducing their combined annual energy demand for space heating and hot water below 60 kWhm2

There are no buildings constructed under the auspices of the project yet
The entire design and construction documentations have been completed by the project for three pilot buildings The documentations have been submitted to the State Construction Expertise for approval In these buildings according to their design the specific annual energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply will be less than 55 kWhm2
Since 2013 12 buildings apart from 3 project pilot buildings above are being designed using principles grounded and promoted by the project In these buildings the energy consumption for space heating already reduced to ca 30 kWhm2

Status of the demonstration projects

Each of the 3 demonstration buildings constructed and reaching the target for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water equal or less than 60 kWhm2 and their energy consumption and other performance living comfort etc monitored for at least one full year Full completion of this outcome without project extension is moderately unlikely because of oneyear delay of the project start If the documented disseminated and institutionalized project results should be based on the results of the three buildings being built then completion of this Outcome without project extension is unlikely

Background studies preconstruction simulations and exploratory designs of measures technological methods installations and equipment for energy efficiency improvement of three pilot buildings and design of all three selected pilot buildings have been completed along with application of integrated building design principles and taking into account new technologies and approaches suggested and formulated by the project
The design and construction documentations of all three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk have been developed and submitted to the state expertise for approval The construction documentation of the pilot building in Hrodna has been approved Such approval for construction documentations of other two buildings is expected in July 2015
The project has already procured of about 15 of all equipment accessories and tools and started procurement procedures for the rest
In line with the commitments assumed in writing by the project partners they have covered the baseline cost of design and construction documentations for all three pilot buildings Recently the GrodnoGrazhdanProject informed the PIU that they will not be able to provide further sustainable financing of the pilot house in Grodno The PIU and UNDP CO have in cooperation with the Head of EE Department approached the Grodno authorities to settle this issue As a result another builder is ready to take over the initiative and commit itself to provide necessary financing of the construction in Grodno The project is currently waiting for a formal letter The two other partners reconfirmed in writing their financial commitments to support the baseline construction proven by corresponding Oblast authorities and submitted timeframes for design and construction of pilot buildings in Minsk and Mogilev
According to the design and construction documentations the energy performance of these buildings will be in line with the outcome target which stipulates for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water supply to be equal or less than 60 kWhm2 and the cost of incremental energy efficiency measures will not exceed 15 of the total construction costs

Demonstrated capacity of the Belarussian building sector specialist to integrate new EE approaches and measures into the design of the buildings and to implement them in practice

comment.narrative:
Nonintegrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force
Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new overall energy performance based norms and standards

Integrated energy efficient building design approach together with buildings overall energy performance based design principles adopted into the work of at least 30 of all local design institutes as well as into the curricula of all educational institutes in Belarus educating new architects and building construction and HVAC engineers
By the end of the project at least 50 experts from each key professional group see outputs 2226 and 200 university students have taken and successfully passed courses on energy efficient building design and constructionKey public authorities responsible for supervision and enforcement of the planned new norms and regulations trained

6
There are already 7 local design institutes ie NIPTIS MAPID Hrodnagrazhdanproekt Gomelgrazhdanproekt SaintGobain Construction Product BelRus Tenth UNR Minskproekt out of ca 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project
The project developed and disseminated about 40 special technical reports and guidelines on energy efficiency design principles The recommendations with cost efficiency analysis of different technical options applicable to the development of energy efficient residential buildings were prepared and discussed with stakeholders The recommendations are intended to be tested during the development of pilot buildings and will be included in national technical regulations and standards
More than 70 specialists
The analysis of target groups along with assessment of needs in their capacity building has been conducted and the capacity building action plan for 20142016 has been compiled discussed with Energy Efficiency Department and other stakeholders and approved Training textbooks have been drafted and disseminated
More than 70 specialists has developed their skills and increased knowledge for leading and managing effective energy audit in residential houses during three twoday training courses organized in Sep Oct and December 2014 One training course was conducted during actual energy audit measurements onsite
More than 70 specialists has taken and passed sixday training courses held in Hrodna and Minsk on energy efficient building design and construction new energy efficiency improvement policy norms and standards The trainings were attended by 29 companies designers engineers builders construction inspectors utilities representatives etc
The project provided support and organized logistics for 9 study visits and 10 international events abroad where about 30 decisionmakers designers builders and other relevant specialists have become acquainted with design construction and operation practices as well as with legal framework standards and policies exercised in four leading European countries Germany Austria England and France in the field of energy efficient residential buildings
No syllabus related to energy efficient building design principles has been adopted into the curricula of target educational institutes in Belarus yet No student has passed the courses yet
The critical analysis of curricula of different relevant universities has been conducted and the proposals for its improvement and updating have been presented in a project report along with a list of suggested university courses Based on the report recommendations for relevant university curricular updates have been drafted presented and approved at two roundtables about 60 representatives of stakeholders have participated
Three new courses related to the best international and national practice in the field of design and construction of energy efficient residential buildings were suggested and presented by the project During roundtable discussions held in the Belarusian National Technical University conjointly with Scientific Council Meeting with presence of representatives from 14 faculties of 7 universities three national universities agreed to include these new courses in their syllabi The decision has been made to continue cooperation with the said faculties in order to further adjust the curricular materials prepared by the project to current syllabi

description.narrative: Strengthened legal and regulatory framework and mechanisms to enforce the legislation for improving the energy efficiency of the building sector with the focus on new residential buildings
Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings

comment.narrative: Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory Uvalues for the building envelope corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWhm2 for space heating of typical multiapartment buildings and 120130 kWh m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation

Revised minimum energy performance standards adopted for new construction and reaching a status of a law by the end of the project with a target of reducing the energy consumption of new residential buildings for space heating and hot water together below 60 kWhm2
An energy performance certification and labelling scheme for both new and existing buildings adopted and under implementation by the end of the project

No minimum energy performance standards reaching a status of a law have been adopted yet
The project elaborated a draft of the Technical Code On Energy Efficiency of Buildings which is based on EU Directive 201031EU concerning integral energy performance of residential buildings along with the list of related national technical regulatory acts These documents were incorporated into the Plan of State Standardization for 2015 and into the State Development Program of Technical Regulation Standardization and Conformity Assessment in the Field of Energy Saving for 20112015 Both programmes were duly adopted and the project submitted the drafts of elaborated documents to the Technical Committee for Standardization in the Field of Energy Efficiency TCS14 for consideration and approval The said TCS14 was created by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction due to initiatives and support provided by the project Three project consultants were coopted to be members of TCS14 and one of them has become a chair of TCS14
As an integral part of national applications to the said Technical Code the project drafted some new standards Some of these standards have been already submitted and adopted in particular Method of calculation of specific heat consumption for heating and ventilation in residential buildings Energy performance of buildings Assessment of overall energy consumption and energy performance of buildings Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification buildings amendments to Thermal protection of buildings Energy performance characteristics Rules of definition
The project has prepared a draft of the methodological guidelines based on the IPMVprotocol and in line with the best international practice and with due account of national provisions for energy audit and energy performance monitoring and calculation applicable to residential buildings The draft has been verified during energy auditing of 30 multistorey residential buildings in 20132015 and adjusted accordingly It will be used for carrying out of energy audits of 25 other multistorey residential buildings in 20152016 and further enter a corresponding adoption procedure Four twoday training workshops were organized and held in 20132014 for more than 70 professional energy auditors
No energy performance certification and labeling scheme for residential buildings have been adopted yet
In technical standard Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification of buildings the project and its partners first introduced a scheme similar to the energy performance certification system This scheme is suggested in a building energy efficiency passport format which is to be issued as an integral part of design and construction documentations and contains all major requisites for energy performance certification Next in the second part of 2015 the project should elaborate practical procedures for the energy certification system and a system of monitoring and compliance checking applicable to residential buildings
To do this the project organized and held two roundtables for relevant stakeholders where main principles and framework of the certification system were discussed and provided further necessary consulting services to the StroyTechNorm RUE and to members of the TCS14 As of Nov 26 2014 the suggestions mentioned above were considered and approved by the said Technical Committee for further adoption procedure The project will continue its efforts in consulting the authorities using in particular such instrument as TCS14 until the said documents are duly adopted

activity-description.narrative: To address the most critical problems of peatland conservation and management and to demonstrate innovative approaches to ecosystem-based climate mitigation and adaptation at one of the largest natural fen mires in Europe, Zvanets peatland, in Drogichin district in Belarus.

description.narrative: second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: To address the most critical problems of peatland conservation and management and to demonstrate innovative approaches to ecosystem-based climate mitigation and adaptation at one of the largest natural fen mires in Europe, Sporovo peatland, in Bereza district in Belarus.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

Output 1 Indicators: 1) Peatland territory cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees within the project. 2) Amount of biomass harvested from peatlands within the project.
Output 2 Indicators: Ecological integrity of the ecosystem (density of indicator species populations, such as Aquatic Warbler, Curlew, Great Snipe), carbon dividends; volumes of biomass harvested, areas of open peatlands freed of shrubs and undergrowth; and groundwater table dynamics.

comment.narrative: Output 1 Baseline: 1) 200 ha at Sporovo fen mire under grassy biomass cleared (implemented as part of an ICI project). 2) 0 tons of biomass harvested within the project. Output 2 Baseline: No system for monitoring of the efficiency of biomass harvesting is in place
1. 3,500 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvanets cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 2,500 tons harvested. 3. A robust monitoring system based on the objectively variable indicators.

1. 2,301 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvanets cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 3,485 tons tons harvested. 3. Water regime monitoring through construction and functioning of water-regulating devices on Zvaniec territory ensured elevation and stabilisation of GWT in 2016 at the favorable for peatland ecosystem levels. Scientific analysis made on the influence of managed fires on peatland ecosystems and prepared appropriate recommendations for the Ministry of Forestry and Ministry of Emergency. Analysis of factors made which determinate peatland overgroving with shrubs and reeds. Data collected on the ecosystems condition after cutting trees, bushes and reed. Received necessary data for preparation of vegetation large-scale maps of the project territories. Calculation of Aquatic Warbler species at the monitoring spots at reserves Zvaniec and Sporauski conducted. Density of Aquatic Warbler species at the sites optimal for nesting exceeds 2015 year quantities in 1.5-2 times. This is indicative of reduced threats and improved quality of habitat for globally threatened species.

1. 3,500 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvaniec cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 2,500 tons of biomass harvested from peatlands 3. A robust monitoring system based on the objectively variable indicators is in place

1. 3,893 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvaniec cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 4,062 tons of biomass harvested from peatlands 3. Monitoring programme for "Zvaniec” and “Sporaŭski” reserves was designed and adjusted based on the practical outputs; monitoring survey of the wetland ecosystems before, during and after the harvesting was completed (indicator species, vegetation proportions, water level monitoring). Monitoring surveys of the vegetation in Reserves were conducted. Large-scale vegetation maps (1:100 000) and maps of succession processes in the ecosystems of the project territories were developed. Monitoring of the globally threatened bird species (Aquatic Warbler, Great Snipe, and Eurasian Curlew) in the mires of the reserves was carried out at 11 sites. Monitoring of the status of populations of indicator insect groups in the mires of Zvaniec and Sporava was carried out. Operating rules for water regulating facilities in the territory of the Zvaniec Reserve were designed. System for precise identification of the carbon dividends is in place.

comment.narrative: 1. Insufficient knowledge and awareness of the benefits of green production and consumption among the public, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and business community. 2. The potential for greening the economy of the Republic of Belarus is underexploited. Economic empowerment of territories based on green growth principles is required in the areas of waste management, water management, biodiversity conservation, ecotourism, and creation of eco-info centres. 3. There are no effective partnerships and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas. NGOs tend to be passive in the implementation of projects aimed at generating added value. NGOs primarily focus on implementation of initiatives related to public information and addressing environmental problems without due regard to economic development aspects as a basis for ensuring sustainability of the results in the future

1. Expanding public knowledge of the principles and ideas of green economy. 2. Developing Green Economy in the regions through implementation of pilot initiatives. 3. Creating effective partnership and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas in such areas as waste management, ecotourism, conservation of biodiversity (aimed at bird or fish conservation, activities at wetlands etc.), renewable energy promotion, etc.

1. 105 publications on project, 1150 stakeholders participated in 10 PR actions, 9000 copies of publications on different directions of green economy, 54770 people visited project web-site and web-pages, 12742 unique visitors of the "green" map data base, 1646 users of electric bus, 40 people were trained in the information ecological center of "Pribuzhskoye Polesie" Nature Reserve, 10300 tourists visited "Svityazyansky" Nature Reserve, the Forum of introduction of ecological decisions into the economy with 175 participants. 2. EUR 2,286,840 were contributed by the project beneficiaries, 22 new jobs were established, business-plans for the implementation of all 4 pilot initiatives were developed and duly approved, financial sustainability of new productions established in the result of implementation of 3 pilot projects is ensured, environmental benefits of new productions established in the result of implementation of4 pilot projects are demonstrated. 3. 16 green initiatives were implemented by 150 NGOs, US$ 92 900 as co-financing were contributed by the NGOs.

1. Expanding public knowledge of the principles and ideas of green economy. 2. Developing Green Economy in the regions through implementation of pilot initiatives. 3. Creating effective partnership and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas in such areas as waste management, ecotourism, conservation of biodiversity (aimed at bird or fish conservation, activities at wetlands etc.), renewable energy promotion, etc.

1. 267 publications and unique references to the project appeared in mass media in 2017: 62 articles in print media and 157 materials in Internet. 29 projects' related radio and 19 TV interviews were given by the project staff and the project stakeholders in 2017. 968 stakeholders from different target groups and of different age increased their awareness on a lot of directions of green economy through organization of 18 PR actions. PR actions were carried out in the pilot project sites and were devoted to a number of the directions of green economy. two videos were developed - on ecotourism development and on the need to hand out used motor oil. 2175 copies of leaflets about the project in English and Russian, development of green transport, implementation of 16 green pilot initiatives, green map, syllabuses of lections on Green Economy in Russian were published and widely disseminated. 80665 visits to the project web-site and web-pages were registered. 12000 unique visitors used "green" map data base, and 51700 entries to the internet resources were registered. 2071 tourists used electric bus . Tower for observation over the birds was constructed on the territory of the "Pribuzhskoye Polesie" Nature Reserve. Two roundtables on promotion of green economy were held. Ecological Forum was organized with around 260 participants from all over the Republic in Vitebsk. 2. high-technological boiler was produced and installed into the boiler-house,boiler-house was repaired, tractor semi-trailer was procured and delivered to Municipal Enterprise "Kommunalnik". Equipment for the production line for processing of the recovered paper into office paper was produced, delivered and installed at Borisov Paper Mill. Separate building for installation of equipment and machinery was constructed at Borisov Paper. 2738232 kg of waste paper were processed into different types pf paper products. capacities for ecological education were created at the grouse nursery th

Preliminary feasibility studies on implementation of a pilot project for the installation of LED street lighting in Novogrudok with systems for monitoring and control and re-equipment and modernization of the city laundry were prepared. The contract for development of a feasibility study of a pilot project for the installation of LED street lighting in Novogrudok with monitoring and control systems was signed. The contractor performed an energy survey of the city's light points, identified the main streets for the replacement of lighting equipment, selected the best options for the equipment and calculated the efficiency of its use.

description.narrative: 1. % of planned oversight activities completed with documented participation by all CCM constituencies. 2. % of CCM members trained on the role of the CCM. 3. % of non-government CCM members with documented selection by their own constituency according to clear criteria.

comment.narrative: No CCM oversight system and CCM oversight activities. Insufficient involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies. Limited capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements.

1. Introduction of CCM oversight system and strengthening CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring with 100% events held. 2. Involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies under the principles of 100% transparency and well documented processes. 3. Strengthening CCM capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements with 100% of CCM members trained on the role of the CCM within the preceding 24 months.

1. For the first time from 2004, 2016 Work plan of Oversight Board was developed and agreed on CCM Meeting on April 4, 2016. In compliance with the plan, 5 official trips to 7 cities where Global Fund Grants` services are provided have been made. O2 meetings of CCM members as NGO representatives with their constituencies were held in 2016 in Viciebsk, Homiel and Hrnly 54,5% events held vs scheduled due to unavailability of Oversight Board members representing state sector to take part in events as per schedule. 2. Elections of CCM members from NGOs were held on December 10 in Minsk under the principles of 100% transparency and well documented processes. 78 representatives from NGOs from 12 cities took part in elections. 3. In terms of strengthening CCM capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements 57% of CCM members and 100% of Oversight board members trained on the role of the CCM in March 2016. A second training to be held in Q1 of 2017.

1. Further strengthening of CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring. 2. Broader involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies. 3. Strengthening CCM capacity in its correspondence to the GFATM requirements and in fulfillment of its main functions.

1. ССM Oversight Committee Plan for 2017 was developed and approved by CCM. The following events were organized and realized in accordance with the Oversight Committee Plan: four regular meetings of the Oversight Committee, six Oversight Committee visits to grant implementation units: 1) Rechitsa-Homiel; 2) Hrodna-Lida; 3) Viciebds-Polack; 4) Homiel-Rechitsa-Svetlahorsk; 5) Mahileu-Babruisk; 6) Salihorsk-Slutsk. Consultant was hired to review and update CCM documents, including Practical Guidance on Monitoring and Analysis and Observation and Analysis Plan. Work plan on sustainability provision for national response to HIV and tuberculosis was worked out. 2 working meetings on evaluation of the Plan on Realization of Sustainable Development of the Prevention and Treatment System for HIV and tuberculosis were held. 2. Four meetings of NGO members with their constituencies and civil society stakeholders were organized in different regions: 1) In Mahileu; 2) In Homiel; 3) In Brest; 4) In Viciebsk. Focus groups have been held among population at high risk of HIV and TB infection to assess the need for HIV/AIDS and TB related services for constituencies. Two trainings for NGO members were organized: 1) On monitoring of rights observation and mechanism of legal regulation of rights of the people with HIV. 2) On effective negotiations. 3. Six CCM meetings were prepared and organized. Four working meetings of CCM working group members were organized. CCM website page was translated into English. Promotional materials with CCM logo were designed and produced.

1. Further strengthening of CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring. 2. Strengthening CCM capacity in its correspondence to the GFATM requirements and in fulfillment of its main functions.

1. ССM Oversight Committee Plan for 2018 was developed and approved by CCM. The work of Consultant on update and review of CCM documents, including Practical Guidance on Monitoring and Analysis and Observation and Analysis Plan was completed. 2. One working meetings of CCM working group members was organized. A training on CCM Orientation with the participation of international trainer from the Global Fund was organized.

• An assessment review of the current system of selection, training and performance evaluation of civil servants in Belarus was conducted by experts of the Academy of Public Administration. The Academy of Public Administration was supported in their work by two international consultants, Professor Jurgita Siugzdiniene, expert in public management, and Mr. Jaba Devdariani, expert in public administration and civil service reform. • Series of seminars organized in cooperation with the Academy of Public Administration to study international practices and experiences in different aspects of processes of selection, training, and evaluation of civil servants: a) Two-day training seminar “Public Service in the Republic of Belarus - Topical Issues of Evaluation of the Impact of the Civil Service System Functioning: Best World Practices and Perspectives of their Use in the Republic of Belarus,” held on 3-4 November 2016. b) One-day training seminar “Public Service in the Republic of Belarus - Topical Issues of Selection: Best World Practices and Perspectives of their Use in the Republic of Belarus,” held on 18 November 2016. c) Conference “Improvement of Internet resources of public administration in accordance with international standards and current practices,” held on 25 November 2016 d) One-day training seminar “Improvement of the existing system of performance evaluation of civil servants,” held on 2 December 2016 with the purpose of studying different methodologies and international experiences of performance evaluation of civil servants, as well as reviewing their corresponding methodologies. e) One-day training seminar “Development of HR policies in public administration,” held on 9 December 2016 aiming at studying different approaches and experiences to civil service and public administration HR-policy management and development. f) Conference “Building civil servants’ capacities to apply the principles of inclusive governance at the national and local level,

Interdepartmental Interaction” was held. • Meetings were organized in the regions of the republic with the purpose of analyzing the locations of future pilot sites for the MFC. The meetings were attended by the representatives of NCLLR, who were responsible for drafting the concept of MFC development within the project. Premises in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Lida were inspected. • Agreement between UNDP and NCLLR has been signed. Main results: - Analytical report on foreign experience of MFC functioning and possibilities of its application in the Republic of Belarus. - The concept of the activity of the Multifunctional Centers in the Republic of Belarus was developed and discussed at the national and local levels, including analysis regarding the possibilities of existing information intermediaries (Belpochta and Beltelecom) in the provision of public services. - Draft Decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus on the activities of multi-functional centers in the Republic of Belarus has been developed. - Regulation on the Procedure for Holding the Contest of Local Initiatives within the framework of the Project designed. 1.1 Expert and technical assistance provided to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as the Secretariat of the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals and Council for Sustainable Development 1.2 Availability of the informational materials on the SDGs 2.1 Number of events with the participation of national and foreign partners on implementation of the SDGs by the Republic of Belarus 2.2 Availability of information materials for promoting the activity of the National Coordinator on implementation of the SDGs, including with participation of the parliamentarians and the Council for Sustainable Development 3.1 Number of study visits abroad of the National Coordinator on implementation of the SDGs and parliamentarians for experience exchange and promotion of the best practices including presentation of the national report by the National Coordinator on implementation of the SDGs in New York (USA) 3.2 Availability of technical assistance to the Parliament in the framework of cooperation with international organizations on the SDGs implementation by the Republic of Belarus 3.3 Availability of advisory and technical assistance in preparation of the national report of the Republic of Belarus on the SDGs implementation

comment.narrative:
The Agenda for Sustainable Development for the period until 2030 (Agenda 2030) was adopted at the UN Summit in 2015. Agenda 2030 sets out the principle "leave no one behind" and is supported by an interlinked set of 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Each country is encouraged to implement the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs to track progress and to inform the UN on the progress of their implementation. The SDGs will be implemented and monitored against national indicators included in the national plans and development strategies. Thus, “localization” is one of the key elements in the implementation of the SDGs. The Parliament plays an important role in supporting all these efforts. The SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals that were successfully achieved by the Republic of Belarus before the deadline. Belarus attaches great importance to the successful implementation of the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs. "Nationalization" of the SDGs has been initiated by the Republic of Belarus with the establishment of the post of National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals and the establishment under his/her leadership the Council for Sustainable Development. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs performs the function of the Secretariat of the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals. Belarus has become one of 44 countries that will present national reviews on SDGs implementation at the political forum of the UN high-level forum on sustainable development in July 2017 at the headquarters of UN in New York.
The UNDP intends to support the efforts of the Government and the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus in implementation of the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs.
The undisputable importance of cooperation between the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus and the United Nations Development Programme stems from the overall shared commitment to support the Parliament’s role in SDGs implementation.
UNDP signed the United Nations

1) Support to the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Ministry of Foreign Affairs as their Secretariat is provided. 2) Informational support on SDGs is provided to the Parliament. 3) Exchange of expertise and best practices on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals through the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Parliament is organized.

Output 1 Support to the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Ministry of Foreign Affairs as their Secretariat is provided. Output 2 Involvement of the Parliament in the issues of SDGs implementation is increased. Output 3 International cooperation in the context of SDGs implementation is enhanced.
